comment._content: It's fascinaing just how many diverse facial patterns the Maker can come up with for the millions! But then again maybe not!  The guy up there in the far right corner doorway bears a fine likeness to Conan O' Brien!

comment.author: 55597723@N02
comment._content: Nice classic photo & Place. Nice expressions. Handsome & Honorable Gentlemen.

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Photo is taken on the steps of the Waterford Chamber of Commerce and Harbour Commissioners building in George's Street Waterford. Once the town house of the Morris family. Built c 1785

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Have added your info into the tags. If you have a second, could you please check the location I have for this building. I think I have it on the correct side of the street, but would like to check if it's in the right section of the street...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: NLI, House is on teh south side of George's Street and faces directly down Gladstone Street in Waterford

comment.author: 39396619@N05
comment._content: desmondg47, you seem to do quite a bit of research. Do you know where I can get info on passengers who left Waterford around  1897 -1902.  Love looking at these old pics.  Great work done by National Library of Ireland.

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: As Ireland was part of the UK at that time, there would have been no record kept as far as i know. Several companies, Waterford Steamship company and its successor the Clyde Shipping company offered sailings from Waterford to Fishguard, Liverpool and even to London i n the period you mention.. These passenger services were in existence up to 1960 (then it was British Rail) and it was a walk on situation at that time.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39396619@N05] As desmondg47 mentions the Clyde Shipping Company, thought you might be interested in this photo taken on board one of their ships that plied from Waterford - the S.S. Copeland - unfortunately we have no passenger names...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
